item.description:
This weekend, I brewed my second cup of coffee with an Aeropress & a Chestnut C2 hand grinder! After a relaxing yoga class, I passed by The Alchemist cafe and spontaneously picked up some Filter Espresso beans to experiment with. These beans, hailing from Guji in Ethiopia, promised a vibrant, citrusy, slightly acidic, and sweet experience, with tasting notes of bergamot, apricot, and blueberry.


The first time I got introduced to my new brewing toys was in Casablanca, during my Morocco trip, as I received them as a gift. It was a very special first brew, from the anticipation of grinding and brewing the medium dark roast beans I roasted myself at a coffee farm in Chiang Mai, Thailand, back in January 2024. The Chestnut C2 hand grinder is super fun to use. It’s incredibly satisfying to feel the beans releasing their aroma as you grind them - an aromatic journey that took only 30 seconds.

The AeroPress itself is also a fascinating product. Its ease of use and straightforward cleaning process impressed me, making the brewing ritual both enjoyable and hassle-free. The best part is both products have such compact design that I could see myself taking them with me on my trips in the future.

Noting down the recipe I used this time for future reference & improvements:

  • Beans:
    • Shakiso Tero (dark roast)
  • Grind:
    • 15g for 250g water (half of my grinder’s capacity)
    • Coarser grind (20 clicks counterclockwise)
  • Brew:
    • Upright Aeropress setup
    • Stir for about 30 seconds
    • Wait for coffee extraction for about 3 minutes (this might be why my brew had a deeper, more bitter taste - can try 2 minutes next time)
    • 1.5 cups of coffee (top-up pour twice)
  • Taste:
    • Slightly bitter and just a tad acidic
    • Very smooth and aromatic
    • Thin texture and easy to drink
    • Sweet and chocolatey aftertaste
item.title: My Brewing Journey
